thread.title: Brexit minister DEMANDS peers 'GET ON WITH THE JOB' and trigger Article 50 in Lords
thread.title_full: Brexit minister DEMANDS peers 'GET ON WITH THE JOB' and trigger Article 50 in Lords

title: Brexit minister DEMANDS peers 'GET ON WITH THE JOB' and trigger Article 50 in Lords

locations.name: north east of the united kingdom

text:
Brexit minister DEMANDS peers 'GET ON WITH THE JOB' and trigger Article 50 in Lords Brexit minister DEMANDS peers 'GET ON WITH THE JOB' and trigger Article 50 in Lords A SENIOR Brexit minister and Conservative peer has blasted the Lords for trying to scupper Theresa May’s Article 50 Bill, saying it is “time to get on with the job”. PUBLISHED: 23:19, Sat, Feb 25, 2017 | UPDATED: 00:52, Sun, Feb 26, 2017 
Lord Bridges lambasted opposers to the Prime Minister’s Brexit bill in the upper house, making clear “the decision taken by people last June 23 won’t be reversed”. 
George Bridges, Baron Bridges of Headley said: “All it provides for is to start the process of leaving the EU. 
“It isn't about the policy choices that flow from exit – those will be for Parliament to discuss and resolve separately and subsequently. 
“We must not forget that the electorate voted into office a Government that had pledged to hold a referendum and to respect its result. GETTY/PARLIAMENT Lord Bridges said it was time for the Lords to let government get on with Brexit Related articles Labour MPs DEMAND inquiry over Russian influence on Brexit vote 
“Parliament then voted to support the holding of that referendum, which posed a very straightforward question; leave or remain? People were told clearly: 'The Government will implement what you decide. The EU referendum is a once in a generation decision.' 
“So the vote of 17.4 million people to leave was not an expression of a viewpoint, but a decision. 
“And as the former Lord Chief Justice, Lord Judge, put it: 'It is simply unacceptable for Parliament - for this House - not to honour its commitments.’” 
Rebel Lords are expected to push back on the Bill before it is passed into law, using veto powers to demand the Government protects the rights of EU citizens in the UK and to give the two houses the final decision on May’s Brexit deal. Brexit: Which parts of the UK had the majority vote? Fri, February 17, 2017 Much of the North East of the United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union including Sunderland, Gateshead, Darlington, Durham, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough, Stockton, Redcar and Cleveland, North Tyneside and South Tyneside, and Northumberland. Newcastle was the only borough to vote to remain. Getty Images 1 of 8 GREAT YARMOUTH: The town of Great Yarmouth on the East Coast of England voted by 72% to leave the European Union. GETTY He called on peers not to tie the PM's hands and start negotiation terms without her 
But Lord Bridges hit out at peers for trying to start the negotiations early by dictating terms to the elected house. 
Writing in the Telegraph, he added: “This is not the place to rehearse the arguments of the referendum, seek to dictate the terms of our exit, or tie the Prime Minister's hands as she prepares to enter negotiations that will be complicated and difficult. 
“Instead, it is time to get on with the job. The UK is committed to its course, and the decision taken by people last June 23 won't be reversed." 
It comes as the Prime Minister is preparing for a tough fight as House of Lords rebels push back on her Brexit plans. GETTY Remoaners have thrown their support behind rebel Lords PARLIAMENT Lord Bridges, who voted remain, said it was time to honour the will of the people 
Mrs May had announced her intention to trigger Article 50 by March but her plans could be delayed as Lords threaten to table ammendments to the Bill. 
The strategy is being hatched by Blair ally Lord Peter Mandelson – who has said he is involved in the Open Britain think tank which is determined to keep Britain as close as possible to the crumbling Brussels bloc. 
Mandelson said: “Critics say ‘what right have I, an unelected peer, to oppose this Bill or even seek to radically amend it?’ 
"But I was appointed by my party, and in the referendum two thirds of Labour electors voted to remain. 
“That’s what I am reflecting, that’s my mandate.” Related articles
